Chapter 6, pages 160 -- 162; Problems 1, 2, 7, 8, 12. Packed decimal is an encoding for integers that uses one half-byte per decimal digit. Sign and magnitude:  The high-order bit represents a sign (0 for positive, 1 for negative) and the other bits represent the magnitude. Thus, 10000 0000 0000 0001 is negative 1 and 0000 0000 0000 0001 is positive 1. One's complement: The representation of a positive number is the same as for sign and magnitude. Thus, it is cheaper to implement than sign and magnitude representa- tion. The disadvantage of one's complement is that there are two represen- tations for zero: positive 0 is 0000 0000 0000 0000 and negative zero is 1111 1111 1111 1111. Two's complement: The representation of a positive number is the same as for sign and magnitude. The representation of a negative number is the bit- wise complement of the corresponding positive number, plus 1. This representation has all the advantages of comple- ment encoding but none of the disadvantages; there is only one zero 0000 0000 0000 0000, and carries off the left end may be ingored.
